headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, Dana. Good morning and welcome, everyone, to our first quarter earnings call. I'm Mike DeWalt, Caterpillar's Vice President of Finance Services. And on the call today, I'm pleased to have our Chairman and CEO, Doug Oberhelman; and our
componenttext:
Thank you very much, Dana. Good morning and welcome, everyone, to our first quarter earnings call. I'm Mike DeWalt, Caterpillar's Vice President of Finance Services. And on the call today, I'm pleased to have our Chairman and CEO, Doug Oberhelman; and our Group President and CFO, Brad Halverson. Remember, this call is copyrighted by Caterpillar Inc., and any use, recording or transmission of any portion of the call without the expressed written consent of Caterpillar is strictly prohibited. If you like a copy of today's call transcript, we'll be posting it in the Investors Section of our caterpillar.com website. It'll be in the section labeled Results Webcast.
This morning, we'll be discussing forward-looking information that involves risks and uncertainties and assumptions that could cause our actual results to differ materially from the forward-looking information. A discussion of some of the factors that either individually or in the aggregate that make actual results differ materially from our projections, that can be found in our cautionary statements under Item 1A, Risk Factors of our Form 10-K filed with the SEC in February of 2015, and it's also in our forward-looking statements language in today's financial release.
In addition, there's a reconciliation of non-GAAP measures that can also be found in this morning's release. And again, it's posted at the caterpillar.com.
Okay, with that, let's get started. This morning, we'll be reviewing financial results for the first quarter and our revised outlook for 2015. And then there are about 3 points that I'd like to start with actually before we get into the detail. And the first is that from a macro standpoint, and in our view, not much has changed since our last earnings conference call in January. So we're staying pretty focused on the things that we do have some control of, and that's execution and operational improvement. Things like safety, quality, market share, efficiency, cost control, inventory turns and cash flow. And we continue to make progress.
And that brings me to my second point. Given the environment we're in, we're pleased with our first quarter results. Sales in the quarter were pretty close to what we expected, and we were pleased with the bottom line.
And that brings me to my third point. And that's a reminder of what we said in our year-end conference call back in January. [ph] We said that we expected the year to start out stronger than it would end, and that's still what we expect. And that's probably evident to you if you consider our first quarter actual results and what we're expecting for the first year.
Okay, with those 3 points, let's get into the quarter. Sales and revenues were $12.7 billion, and that was about 4% less than the $13.2 billion that we had in the first quarter last year. $342 million of that decline in sales was a result of a stronger dollar, and sales volume was unfavorable $295 million. Those 2 items were partially offset by a small improvement in price realization. That was $105 million, definitely in the right direction, but less than 1%.
Now the only region in the world that was up was North America, and that was up 9%. The North American improvement was pretty much across the board in each of our -- with each of our segments being in positive territory.
Outside of North America, that wasn't the case, and sales in each of our segments were down in Latin America, Europe Africa/Middle East and in the Asia Pacific region. In total, sales and revenues were off 18% in Latin America, and sales of all of our equipment segments, that's Resource Industries, Construction Industries and Energy & Transportation were down double digits. Construction was off 23%, and a sizable portion of that was the absence of a large order from the Brazilian government that we had in the first quarter last year and weaker construction activity in general in the region, particularly Brazil. Resource Industries was also down 23% in Latin America, reflecting continuing weakness in mining. And that's pretty much the case in every region. And Energy & Transportation was down 11%.
Sales and revenues in the Europe Africa/Middle East region were down 12%. Construction Industries was off 14%, and most of that was from less favorable dealer inventory changes and the impact of currency on our sales.
Resource Industries was also off 14%, again weak mining. And Energy & Transportation was down 8%.
Sales and revenues in Asia Pacific were down 13%, with the most significant decline in Construction Industries at 21%. Construction Industries were down substantially in China and lower in Japan as a result of the stronger dollar versus the yen. Our sales in Japan, which are in yen, essentially translated into fewer dollars. Okay, that's a recap of sales.
Profit per share, though, was higher in the first quarter than it was in the first quarter a year ago. This year, it was $1.81 per share. A year ago, in the first quarter, it was $1.44 a share.
Now we had restructuring cost in both quarters. In the first quarter of last year, we had $0.17 per share of restructuring cost, and that was mostly from the actions that we took in our European operations. This year, we had $0.05 per share of restructuring costs in the first quarter. So excluding restructuring, profit per share improved from $1.61 a year ago to $1.86 in the current quarter -- in the first quarter. Now the primary reason profit per share was up was: number one was the $120 million gain that we had from the sale of our remaining ownership in what was our third-party logistics business. We also had, as I mentioned a minute ago, $105 million of positive price realization, and we had $77 million of favorable currency impact that helped operating profit. And I'm just going to stop there for a minute and chat about currency. It's a subject that, for us, seems to be frequently misunderstood. Now I'd just like to clarify things again. We do have substantial sales that are in currencies other than the U.S. dollar. And when the dollar strengthens, that causes those sales to translate into fewer dollars, and that's a negative for our top line. That said, we also have substantial manufacturing operations and we source substantial purchase material outside the U.S. So our factories outside the U.S. allows sourcing outside the U.S. And that results in lower cost when translated to U.S. dollars. And that's exactly what happened this quarter. Sales translated into fewer dollars. As I mentioned a little bit ago, $342 million fewer. However, the impact on cost was favorable $419 million, and the net operating profit was positive $77 million. While we're not 100% exactly balanced in our currency exposures, we do have reasonably offsetting sales and cost positions that usually keep the profit impact of exchange rates swings to a reasonably manageable level. Okay, that's the story on currency. I'll kind of get back to profit now.
I'd already talked about the positive items, and offsetting those positives for the quarter, we did have lower sales volume, and that was negative to our operating profit, about $83 million, and we had higher cost. The most significant cost factor was a change in the timing of expense related to divesting of stock-based compensation. The timing change won't have an impact on full year versus 2014, but it did add to the costs in the first quarter. Okay, that's a quick run-through of profit versus the first quarter last year.
Let's turn to the balance sheet and cash flow. Machinery and Energy & Transportation operating cash flow was a little over $1 billion in the quarter, but that was about $800 million lower than the first quarter last year. And most of that decline came from higher incentive compensation payments in the first quarter of this year, and they are based on performance in 2014. We used about $400 million of cash in the quarter to repurchase shares. And with relatively modest needs for CapEx this year, we currently expect to continue to repurchase shares in 2015. And as you might expect, the timing and the amount that we ultimately repurchase, well, that will be subject to business and market conditions as we progress through the year and our cash appointment priority. Our balance sheet remained strong with a debt to total capital ratio of 37.1%. And that's about right in the middle of our targeted 30% to 45% range. And it was slightly favorable versus year-end 2014. If you net cash with the debt, our net debt to capital ratio at the end of the quarter was 18.3%.
Now before we get into the revised outlook, I'll just recap changes in the order backlog over the last quarter because I suspect many of you are interested in that. We ended the first quarter with an order backlog of $16.5 billion, and that's about $800 million lower than the year-end 2014. The decline was split between Construction Industries and Resource Industries. You might have expected that Energy & Transportation would've also declined from year-end as a result of weakness in the oil industry. It was in total, however, about flat. We did have a decline in the backlog because of weakness in oil, but that was about offset by an increase in the backlog for locomotives.
Okay, with that, let me go through the 2015 outlook. As I've started out, in terms of overall world economic growth, we don't expect much change from the outlook that we've provided with our year-end results in January. And the same goes for our sales and revenues. We're holding it at about $50 billion for 2015. Now while we're not changing the sales outlook, just as a reminder, we do expect 2015 to be over $5 billion lower than 2014. And as we said last January, and I'll reiterate today, the impact of substantially lower oil prices is the most significant reason for the decline. And we still think the most significant impact from oil will be from engines and other equipment that we sell for drilling and well servicing. And that's the spot where we expect a large drop in demand this year. We've already started to see the impact of that in our order backlog as new orders have not kept pace with sales and the backlog is declining. And we'll start seeing that its sales over the course of [indiscernible] We also expect that indirect effects from substantially lower oil prices will be negative in 2015 versus 2014. In countries and in some regions of the U.S. where oil production is significant to either government receipts or for the local economies, it will likely be negative for sales of construction equipment and for electric power generation business. In some cases, it can be fairly direct like building a road to service a new well. Or it can be very indirect, like construction spending in a country where the government relies on oil revenue to fund spending. Because many of those construction-related impacts are indirect, it does make it tough to measure. But anecdotally, we believe we're already starting to see the impact of that in our Construction business.
Now in addition to oil, there are several other factors that are contributing to the year-over-year decline in sales. The stronger dollar is a headwind to sales, but again not profit. Commodity prices and mining are generally weak, particularly iron ore and coal, and that's negative for mining and our Resource Industries segment. With weaknesses in agriculture, we're expecting lower sales of industrial engines. And we expect our rail business to be down in 2015, after a great year in 2014. And we expect weakness in the Construction Industries of key developing countries like China and Brazil. And that was certainly evident in our first quarter. So that's a recap of our year-over-year changes down from 2014, but no change in the top line outlook for 2015. We did raise the profit outlook again this morning. Our previous outlook was $4.60 per share all in and $4.75 excluding restructuring costs. This morning, we raised the profit outlook to $4.70 per share all in and $5 per share excluding restructuring costs. Now the changes from the previous outlook include more restructuring activity. We've increased our restructuring cost estimate from about $150 million expected for the year, up $100 million to about $250 million, with almost all of the increase related to facilities that produce mining products. We added the $120 million gain in the first quarter on the sale of our remaining ownership in the third-party logistics business. That wasn't in our previous outlook. And based on our first quarter actual results, we made some additional improvements to the profit outlook. While we held the top line and made a modest improvement to the bottom line of our outlook, 2015 is still shaping up to be an uncertain and challenging year. There continues to be softness in Latin America, particularly Brazil. China growth is concerning. The stability and scale of economic recovery in the United States remains concerning. Europe is still a question mark. Mining hasn't shown improvement yet. And while we're still planning a sharp decline in our oil-related sales in 2015, there's still a concern around that.
So to wrap up and move on to the Q&A portion of the call, sales and revenues in the first quarter were about as we expected, and we had a solid profit quarter. We repurchased 400 million of shares in the quarter. The balance sheet remains strong, and we're very focused on operational performance and cost control. But it still looks like a tough year and we've not seen meaningful signs of recovery in many of our cyclical businesses.
So with that, we're ready to move on to the Q&A portion of the call.

componenttext: Yes, I mean, we did have an inventory build in the first quarter. We didn't talk a lot about that in the release. And partly because, I think sometimes it gets taken out of context. We expect an inventory build in the first quarter. The selling season from dealers to end customers tends to be heavier in the summertime, and so the dealers add inventories ahead of summertime. That occurred this year in Construction Industries. We have order of magnitude of 180 million dealers or 180 dealers roughly around the world. And at any given point in time, you've got some of them that probably have a little too much and some that have probably a little too little. If we look at our months of supply on hand, we kind of try to judge that in a reasonable range. We do look back by region. And by and large, I think our dealer inventory, we'd say, is in a reasonable range. Now from here, we definitely believe it will come down over the course of the year. That happened last year. That's kind of normal to have a build in the first quarter and then have dealers fill that down as we go through the year.

So my guess is, coming off of a pretty light quarter for cost and some increase in engineering as the year goes by, probably not a lot of change in the top line, margin will probably moderate from where it's at.

componenttext: Yes. So I think this really goes kind of across the company. I'll touch on several of the segments. But we expect that the first quarter was kind of seasonally low on costs. So just as a matter of course, discretionary cost will go up a bit from the first quarter level. We do plan to spend some more on R&D. And we talked about that last January. We're looking at negative mix. We'll have negative product mix in E&T because of the decline in the oil business that's coming. We also expect some negative mix in Construction Industries. If you look at what they sold in the first quarter, it was relatively balanced between -- we have 3 pieces of construction, earthmoving, excavation and building construction products or ECB, our smaller equipment. So what we actually sold in the quarter, at least in terms of new equipment, was fairly balanced between those 3 subsectors. But if you look at what was ordered and what we think is going to happen for sales as the year unfolds, probably not a lot of change in total for construction, but a bit more of a shift to BCP, smaller machines. I think part of that is, in countries like China where the selling season is very late in the year, that helped excavation sales and then that pales down later in the year. So we're looking at some negative mix in construction as the year goes on. I don't think, for the year, we're not, at least in our contemplated in our outlook, we're not going to fall below double-digit for construction. E&T, operating profit percent, well, I think, for sure, come down. Or I guess, I can't say for sure. We would expect it would come down, and mostly because of the declines in the oil business, which is -- tends to be bigger, a little bit higher-margin product.

componenttextpreview: There's -- that's a good question, and it's interesting. When the numbers get this small, sometimes, we end up talking so much about numbers that are relatively small. I mean, we had, for the company overall, $105 million of price realization. That's less
componenttext: There's -- that's a good question, and it's interesting. When the numbers get this small, sometimes, we end up talking so much about numbers that are relatively small. I mean, we had, for the company overall, $105 million of price realization. That's less than 1%. I think the segment that is doing -- the segments that are doing better right now are construction and Energy & Transportation. Construction, in particular, did a little bit better. But part of that is really from a few -- 3 things. One is we had last year this big Brazilian order from the government. And while that was good volume, it was pretty low price. So without that, sort of our average price level is up a bit. We had some favorable geographic mix, and we did take list price increases small, but up at the beginning of the year. So that all contributed a bit. I think with Resource Industries, it's been down year-over-year for the last -- certainly, the last couple of quarters. I can't remember the third, but probably the third last year as well. It's just a tough business right now. It's dog eat dog. And although a lot of that product that we sell is dollar-based, the sales are conducted in dollars a lot in mining. Some of our key competition like Komatsu probably has more of yen cost base than [indiscernible] being aggressive. So it's a tough industry.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll add. Doug Oberhelman here. Mike said it's dog eat dog. But I'd rather say cat eat dog. But be that as it may, we are seeing a very competitive marketplace right now. We did post up a little price realization in the first quarter, which I was very hap
componenttext: I'll add. Doug Oberhelman here. Mike said it's dog eat dog. But I'd rather say cat eat dog. But be that as it may, we are seeing a very competitive marketplace right now. We did post up a little price realization in the first quarter, which I was very happy to see, but I will tell you, with the yen, that's off over 50% in 3 years. Euro, Brazilian currency, pound currency off 20% to 30% in the last year. You know all of our competitors aren't in the U.S. So it's a -- it really is a competitive environment out there, but we are not giving up our pins goals, our market share goals. We're doing as well as we can be expected in a tough market that we are. Certainly, our cost management the last couple of years has helped that. Our lean manufacturing, where we generated cost advantage, has helped. And we're still very much focused on market here. But I would say the competition for every deal has gotten greater as we've seen this dollar strengthened.

componenttext: Right. JPMorgan. My first question, it's really -- I post it to Doug. We talked about Europe and the euro being weak. And what's that doing to help the European manufacturers export. But are you seeing any signs of European economies getting any better at all? Or is that something that you think might be on the up-and-coming going into '16?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think it's in our future. I said on the show this morning that it seems to me that with the QE coming by the ECB, with the euro that's off, like I said, 25% or so in a year's time, with energy prices where they are, the stimulus of all 3 of those, and n
componenttext: I think it's in our future. I said on the show this morning that it seems to me that with the QE coming by the ECB, with the euro that's off, like I said, 25% or so in a year's time, with energy prices where they are, the stimulus of all 3 of those, and not to mention continuing lowered rates, which has finally happened across Europe, I liken the Eurozone an awful lot to the period of, say, 2010, '11, and '12 in the U.S. where there was a lot of stimulus. We didn't see much growth, but we've seen better growth now. So I am convinced it's coming. I don't know if it will be -- when it will be. And I'm not going to predict that. But we still see, and I was just with several of our European dealers. We still have the North and South divide. I think the Germans would say they see some green shoots in the economy. We're not seeing it in our numbers. But they were a bit more optimistic in Germany. Of course, a euro at 1 07 8 really benefits those exporters. componenttext: No, no, it's good. It's Brad. Let me talk a little bit about this. There's been a lot of discussions about it, and we've been fairly active in terms of the studies that we do here. componenttext:
Thank you very much, Dana. And good morning and welcome, everyone, to our first quarter earnings call. I'm Mike DeWalt, Caterpillar's Vice President of Finance Services. And on the call today, I'm pleased to have our Chairman and CEO, Doug Oberhelman; and our Group President and CFO, Brad Halverson. Remember, this call is copyrighted by Caterpillar Inc., and any use, recording or transmission of any portion of the call without the expressed written consent of Caterpillar is strictly prohibited. If you like a copy of today's call transcript, we'll be posting it in the Investors Section of our caterpillar.com website. It'll be in the section labeled Results Webcast.
This morning, we'll be discussing forward-looking information that involves risks and uncertainties and assumptions that could cause our actual results to differ materially from the forward-looking information. A discussion of some of the factors that either individually or in the aggregate could make actual results differ materially from our projections, that can be found in our cautionary statements under Item 1A, Risk Factors of our Form 10-K filed with the SEC in February of 2015, and it's also in our forward-looking statements language in today's financial release.
In addition, there's a reconciliation of non-GAAP measures that can also be found in this morning's release. And again, it's posted at caterpillar.com.
Okay. With that, let's get started. This morning, we'll be reviewing financial results for the first quarter and our revised outlook for 2015. And then, there are about 3 points that I'd like to start with actually before we get into the details. And the first is that from a macro standpoint, in our view, not much has changed since our last earnings conference call in January. So we're staying pretty focused on the things that we do have some control of, and that's execution and operational improvement. Things like safety, quality, market share, efficiency, cost control, inventory turns and cash flow. And we continue to make progress.
And that brings me to my second point. Given the environment we're in, we were pleased with our first quarter results. Sales in the quarter were pretty close to what we expected, and we were pleased with the bottom line.
And that brings me to my third point. And that's a reminder of what we said in our year-end conference call back in January. We said that we expected the year to start out stronger than it would end, and that's still what we expect. And that's probably evident to you if you consider our first quarter actual results and what we're expecting for the first year.
Okay. With those 3 points, let's get into the quarter. Sales and revenues were $12.7 billion, and that was about 4% less than the $13.2 billion that we had in the first quarter last year. $342 million of that decline in sales was a result of a stronger dollar, and sales volume was unfavorable $295 million. Those 2 items were partially offset by a small improvement in price realization. That was $105 million, definitely in the right direction, but less than 1%.
Now the only region in the world that was up was North America, and that was up 9%. The North American improvement was pretty much across the board in each of our -- with each of our segments being in positive territory.
Outside of North America, that wasn't the case, and sales in each of our segments were down in Latin America, Europe, Africa, Middle East and in the Asia Pacific region. In total, sales and revenues were off 18% in Latin America, and sales of all of our equipment segments, that's Resource Industries, Construction Industries and Energy & Transportation were down double digits. Construction was off 23%, and a sizable portion of that was the absence of a large order from the Brazilian government that we had in the first quarter last year and weaker construction activity in general in the region, particularly Brazil. Resource Industries was also down 23% in Latin America, reflecting continuing weakness in mining. And that's pretty much the case in every region. And Energy & Transportation was down 11%.
Sales and revenues in the Europe, Africa, Middle East region were down 12%. Construction Industries was off 14%, and most of that was from less favorable dealer inventory changes and the impact of currency on our sales.
Resource Industries was also off 14%, again, weak mining. And Energy & Transportation was down 8%.
Sales and revenues in Asia Pacific were down 13%, with the most significant decline in Construction Industries at 21%. Construction Industries were down substantially in China and lower in Japan as a result of the stronger dollar versus the yen. Our sales in Japan, which are in yen, essentially translated into fewer dollars. 
Okay. That's a recap of sales. Profit per share, though, was higher in the first quarter than it was in the first quarter a year ago. This year, it was $1.81 per share. A year ago, in the first quarter, it was $1.44 a share.
Now we had restructuring cost in both quarters. In the first quarter of last year, we had $0.17 per share of restructuring cost, and that was mostly from the actions that we took in our European operations. This year, we had $0.05 per share of restructuring costs in the first quarter. So excluding restructuring, profit per share improved from $1.61 a year ago to $1.86 in the current quarter -- in the first quarter. Now the primary reason profit per share was up, number one, was the $120 million gain that we had from the sale of our remaining ownership in what was our third-party logistics business. We also had, as I mentioned a minute ago, $105 million of positive price realization, and we had $77 million of favorable currency impact that helped operating profit. And I'm just going to stop here for a minute and chat about currency. It's a subject that, for us, seems to be frequently misunderstood. Now I'd just like to clarify things again. We do have substantial sales that are in currencies other than the U.S. dollar. And when the dollar strengthens, that causes those sales to translate into fewer dollars, and that's a negative for our top line. That said, we also have substantial manufacturing operations and we source substantial purchase material outside the U.S. So our factories outside the U.S. allows sourcing outside the U.S. And that results in lower cost when translated to U.S. dollars. And that's exactly what happened this quarter. Sales translated into fewer dollars. As I mentioned a little bit ago, $342 million fewer. However, the impact on cost was favorable $419 million, and the net to operating profit was positive $77 million. While we're not 100% exactly balanced in our currency exposures, we do have reasonably offsetting sales and cost positions that usually keep the profit impact of exchange rate swings to a reasonably manageable level. 
Okay. That's the story on currency. I'll kind of get back to profit now. I'd already talked about the positive items, and offsetting those positives for the quarter, we did have lower sales volume, and that was negative to our operating profit, about $83 million, and we had higher cost. The most significant cost factor was a change in the timing of expense related to divesting of stock-based compensation. The timing change won't have an impact on full year versus 2014, but it did add to cost in the first quarter. 
Okay. That's a quick run-through of profit versus the first quarter last year. Let's turn to the balance sheet and cash flow. Machinery, Energy & Transportation operating cash flow was a little over $1 billion in the quarter, but that was about $800 million lower than the first quarter last year. And most of that decline came from higher incentive compensation payments in the first quarter of this year, and they are based on performance in 2014. We used about $400 million of cash in the quarter to repurchase shares. And with relatively modest needs for CapEx this year, we currently expect to continue to repurchase shares in 2015. And as you might expect, the timing and the amount that we ultimately repurchase, well, that will be subject to business and market conditions as we progress through the year and on our cash deployment priorities. Our balance sheet remains strong with a debt to total capital ratio of 37.1%. And that's about right in the middle of our targeted 30% to 45% range. And it was slightly favorable versus year-end 2014. If you net cash with the debt, our net debt to capital ratio at the end of the quarter was 18.3%.
Now before we get into the revised outlook, I'll just recap changes in the order backlog over the last quarter because I suspect many of you are interested in that. We ended the first quarter with an order backlog of $16.5 billion, and that's about $800 million lower than the year-end 2014. The decline was split between Construction Industries and Resource Industries. You might have expected that Energy & Transportation would've also declined from year-end as a result of weakness in the oil industry. It was, in total, however, about flat. We did have a decline in the backlog because of weakness in oil, but that was about offset by an increase in the backlog for locomotives.
Okay. With that, let me go through the 2015 outlook. As I've started out, in terms of overall world economic growth, we don't expect much change from the outlook that we provided with our year-end results in January. And the same goes for our sales and revenues, we're holding it at about $50 billion for 2015. 
Now while we're not changing the sales outlook, just as a reminder, we do expect 2015 to be over $5 billion lower than 2014. And as we said last January, and I'll reiterate today, the impact of substantially lower oil prices is the most significant reason for the decline. And we still think the most significant impact from oil will be from engines and other equipment that we sell for drilling and well servicing. And that's the spot where we expect a large drop in demand this year. We've already started to see the impact of that in our order backlog as new orders have not kept pace with sales, and the backlog is declining. And we'll start seeing that hit sales over the course of 2015. We also expect that indirect effects from substantially lower oil prices will be negative in 2015 versus 2014. In countries and in some regions of the U.S. where oil production is significant for either government receipts or for the local economies, it will likely be negative for sales of construction equipment and for our electric power generation business. In some cases, it can be fairly direct like building a road to service a new well, or it can be very indirect, like construction spending in a country where the government relies on oil revenue to fund spending. Because many of those construction-related impacts are indirect, it does make it tough to measure. But anecdotally, we believe we're already starting to see the impacts of that in our Construction business.
Now in addition to oil, there are several other factors that are contributing to the year-over-year decline in sales. The stronger dollar is a headwind to sales, but again, not profit. Commodity prices in mining are generally weak, particularly iron ore and coal, and that's negative for mining in our Resource Industries segment. With weaknesses in agriculture, we're expecting lower sales of industrial engines. And we expect our rail business to be down in 2015 after a great year in 2014. And we expect weakness in the Construction Industries of key developing countries like China and Brazil. And that was certainly evident in our first quarter. So that's a recap of our year-over-year changes, down from 2014, but no change in the top line outlook for 2015. We did raise the profit outlook again this morning. Our previous outlook was $4.60 per share all-in, and $4.75 excluding restructuring costs. This morning, we raised the profit outlook to $4.70 per share all-in, and $5 per share excluding restructuring costs. 
Now the changes from the previous outlook include more restructuring activity. We've increased our restructuring cost estimate from about $150 million expected for this year, up $100 million to about $250 million, with almost all of the increase related to facilities that produce mining products. We added the $120 million gain in the first quarter on the sale of our remaining ownership in the third-party logistics business that wasn't in our previous outlook. And based on our first quarter actual results, we made some additional improvements to the profit outlook. While we held the top line and made a modest improvement to the bottom line of our outlook, 2015 is still shaping up to be an uncertain and challenging year. There continues to be softness in Latin America, particularly Brazil. China growth is concerning. The stability and scale of economic recovery in the United States remains concerning. Europe is still a question mark. Mining hasn't shown improvement yet. And while we're still planning a sharp decline in our oil-related sales in 2015, there's still a concern around that.
So to wrap up and move on to the Q&A portion of the call, sales and revenues in the first quarter were about as we expected, and we had a solid profit quarter. We repurchased 400 million of shares in the quarter. The balance sheet remains strong, and we're very focused on operational performance and cost control. But it still looks like a tough year and we've not seen meaningful signs of recovery in many of our cyclical businesses.
So with that, we're ready to move on to the Q&A portion of the call.

componenttext: I would say not that it was not previously anticipated. I mean, we did expect benefits from restructuring to be better this year. So no, I wouldn't say we added anything for that. Now we did add to restructuring costs. And down the road, after those are complete, those should definitely lead to more benefits. But actually, in the short term, there are related costs for things like rearrangement that aren't included in the number that can tend to be a little bit negative around the time you're actually doing it. So I'd say, on balance, that is relative to our original outlook, not a big reason for change. We took the profit outlook up, mostly because of very good cost control in the first quarter. I know we don't give quarterly guidance, but we were a little better than we thought we were going to be in the quarter. And some of that, of course, was timing. But some of it is spending that we don't think we'll have to make as the year goes on.

componenttext: Actually, material cost control has been a real positive actually, not just in the first quarter, but over the past few years. The team has done a great job. That's a combination of the purchasing group and the design group in terms of designing for cost reduction. So it's been pretty good. It was a decent positive again in the first quarter. If memory serves me, it was in the neighborhood of 1.5%. Now we -- there -- to the extent that we buy things in non-U.S. currencies, we wouldn't be including it in that kind of number. We isolate the impact of currency on our expenses separately, at least for those that are denominated in foreign currencies.

componenttext: Okay. And my follow-up on dealer inventory side. How should we think about inventory levels over the balance of the year? And out of the inventory build that we saw on the quarter, is it in the right regions? Is it in areas that you focus on?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, we did have an inventory build in the first quarter. And we didn't talk a lot about that in the release. And partly because, I think, sometimes, it gets taken out of context. We expect an inventory build in the first quarter. The selling seas
componenttext: Yes, I mean, we did have an inventory build in the first quarter. And we didn't talk a lot about that in the release. And partly because, I think, sometimes, it gets taken out of context. We expect an inventory build in the first quarter. The selling season from dealers to end customers tends to be heavier in the summertime, and so dealers add the inventories ahead of summertime. That occurred this year in Construction Industries. We have order of magnitude of 180 million dealers -- or 180 dealers roughly around the world. And at any given point in time, you've got some of them that probably have a little too much and some that have probably a little too little. If we look at our months of supply on hand, we kind of try to judge that in a reasonable range and we do look at that by region. And by and large, I think, our dealer inventory, we would say, is in a reasonable range. Now from here, we definitely believe it will come down over the course of the year. That happened last year. That's kind of normal to have a build in the first quarter and then have dealers sell that down as we go through the year.

componenttext: It's RBC. I wanted to ask about the Resource Industries segment. The margin there in the first quarter actually went up sequentially even though revenue was down. I mean, do you feel like the margin has bottomed in that business at this point?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, I wouldn't say that, Seth. I think, if you look at it sequentially, you always have to consider that we have some reasonable seasonality between the first quarter and the fourth quarter -- or fourth quarter to first quarter in discretionary cost. So f
componenttext: No, I wouldn't say that, Seth. I think, if you look at it sequentially, you always have to consider that we have some reasonable seasonality between the first quarter and the fourth quarter -- or fourth quarter to first quarter in discretionary cost. So fourth quarter was a pretty heavy quarter, first quarter was a pretty light quarter in terms of spending. So I think that has a lot to do with the sequential improvement. Now I think, Resource Industries margins will likely come down as the year progresses. We kind of said before we thought something around breakeven was probably reasonable. I think that we're going to add the spending over the course of the year. We've got some R&D programs that we need to do there. We talked about that in January. So my guess is, coming off of a pretty light quarter for cost and some increase in engineering as the year goes by, and probably not a lot of change in the top line, margin will probably moderate from where it's at.

componenttext: Okay. And then, if I could just ask a follow-up on the aftermarket business for Resource was down, revenue was down. Is there any kind of light at the end of the tunnel there? Is that -- what do you think needs to happen there for the aftermarket business to get better on mining?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's a very good question. We've been asking ourselves that. We've got customers with some parked equipment. We think, again, there's been some cannibalizing of equipment in the field. We're looking -- I think, customers are pushing out rebuild tim
componenttext: Yes, that's a very good question. We've been asking ourselves that. We've got customers with some parked equipment. We think, again, there's been some cannibalizing of equipment in the field. We're looking -- I think, customers are pushing out rebuild times. In our view, that can't keep happening, but it has been happening. So when that turns around, it's like the industry overall. It's a little bit hard to predict the timing. But we understand where both part sales and equipment sales are to what's, at least for equipment, a reasonable replacement level. It's far below that. But when that's going to turn around, it's hard to say.

componenttextpreview: We've talked about breakeven in Resource. Can you talk to us about what we should expect profitability-wise, which were very impressive in both construction and in E&T. [indiscernible] but you did north of $0.15 on the 16% in construction and over 20% in
componenttext: We've talked about breakeven in Resource. Can you talk to us about what we should expect profitability-wise, which were very impressive in both construction and in E&T. [indiscernible] but you did north of $0.15 on the 16% in construction and over 20% in E&T. And while we expect to come down, in order to hold the guidance where you are, these have to come down quite a bit. Could you give me some idea of what we should expect, and do these things, if construction go below double-digit operating margin for the year, what happens as the year unfolds and the business weakens?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think, this really goes kind of across the company. I'll touch on several of the segments. But we expect that the first quarter was kind of seasonally low on costs. So just as a matter of course, discretionary cost will go up a bit from the firs
componenttext: Yes. So I think, this really goes kind of across the company. I'll touch on several of the segments. But we expect that the first quarter was kind of seasonally low on costs. So just as a matter of course, discretionary cost will go up a bit from the first quarter level. We do plan to spend some more on R&D. And we talked about that last January. We're looking at negative mix. We'll have negative product mix in E&T because of the decline in the oil business that's coming. We also expect some negative mix in Construction Industries. If you look at what they sold in the first quarter, it was relatively balanced between -- we have 3 pieces of construction, earthmoving, excavation and building construction products, or BCP, our smaller equipment. So what we actually sold in the quarter, at least in terms of new equipment, was fairly balanced between those 3 subsectors. But if you look at what was ordered and what we think is going to happen for sales as the year unfolds, probably not a lot of change in total for construction, but a bit more of a shift to BCP, smaller machines. I think, part of that is, in countries like China where the selling season is very early in the year, that helps excavation sales and then that tails down later in the year. So we're looking at some negative mix in construction as the year goes on. I don't think, for the year, we're not, at least in our -- contemplated in our outlook, we're not going to fall below double digits for construction. E&T operating profit percent will, I think, for sure, come down. Or I don't know, I guess, I can't say for sure. We would expect it would come down, and mostly because of the declines in the oil business, which is -- tends to be bigger, a little bit higher-margin product.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: And can you follow up, we talked a little bit about what's going on in pricing across the businesses? I mean, you did signal out some of the problems in the Resource business was basically pricing more than anything else. So what's going on in the other 2
componenttext: And can you follow up, we talked a little bit about what's going on in pricing across the businesses? I mean, you did signal out some of the problems in the Resource business was basically pricing more than anything else. So what's going on in the other 2 sectors, pricing-wise? It seems relatively holding? Or is it somewhat price competition showing up?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: There's -- that's a good question, and it's interesting. When the numbers get this small, sometimes, we end up talking too much about numbers that are relatively small. I mean, we had, for the company overall, $105 million of price realization. That's les
componenttext: There's -- that's a good question, and it's interesting. When the numbers get this small, sometimes, we end up talking too much about numbers that are relatively small. I mean, we had, for the company overall, $105 million of price realization. That's less than 1%. I think, the segment that is doing -- the segments that are doing better right now are Construction and Energy & Transportation. Construction, in particular, did a little bit better. But part of that is really from a few -- 3 things. One is we had last year this big Brazilian order from the government. And while that was good volume, it was pretty low price. So without that, sort of our average price level is up a bit. We had some favorable geographic mix, and we did take list price increases, small, but up at the beginning of the year. So that all contributed a bit. I think, with Resource Industries, it's been down year-over-year for the last -- certainly, last couple of quarters. I can't remember the third, but probably in the third last year as well. It's just a tough business right now. It's dog eat dog. And although a lot of that product that we sell is dollar-based, the sales are conducted in dollars a lot in mining, some of our key competition like Komatsu probably has more of yen cost base than we do, and they're being aggressive. So it's a tough industry.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll add. Doug Oberhelman here. Mike said, dog eat dog. I'd rather say it cat eats dog. But be that as it may, we are seeing a very competitive marketplace right now. We did post up a little price realization in the first quarter, which I was very happy t
componenttext: I'll add. Doug Oberhelman here. Mike said, dog eat dog. I'd rather say it cat eats dog. But be that as it may, we are seeing a very competitive marketplace right now. We did post up a little price realization in the first quarter, which I was very happy to see, but I will tell you, with the yen, that's off over 50% in 3 years. Euro, Brazilian currency, pound currency, off 20% to 30% in the last year. You know all of our competitors aren't in the U.S., so it's a -- it really is a competitive environment out there, but we are not giving up our pins goals, our market share goals. We're doing as well as we can be expected in a tough market that we are. Certainly, our cost management the last couple of years has helped that. Our lean manufacturing, where we generated cost advantage, has helped. And we're still very much focused on market here. But I would say the competition for every deal has gotten greater as we've seen this dollar strengthen.

componenttext: I think, it's in our future. We didn't see much growth, but we see better growth now. So I am convinced it's coming. I don't know if it will be -- when it will be. And I'm not going to predict that. But we still see, and I was just with several of our European dealers. We still have the North and South divide. I think, the Germans would say, they see some green shoots in that economy. componenttextpreview: No, it's good. Andy, it's Brad. Let me talk a little bit about this. There's been a lot of discussion about it, and we've been fairly active in terms of the studies that we do here. We'll go through a process where we are cyclical, we've seen this before.
componenttext: No, it's good. Andy, it's Brad. Let me talk a little bit about this. There's been a lot of discussion about it, and we've been fairly active in terms of the studies that we do here. We'll go through a process where we are cyclical, we've seen this before. On the one side, we want to be ready for the upturn. Our business model is to produce quality products, lowest on our operating costs, produces parts and service for us and the dealers and repeat business. And so on that side, given the fact that our sales can move fairly dramatically through the cycles, we want to be ready to be able to meet that demand. But on the other side, it's absolutely clear and a good question that this current economic environment presents a lot of opportunities. So we've been at this since 2013. In fact, if you kind of add up what we've done in the last 3 years, including what we plan to do in '15, we'll incur roughly $900 million of restructuring cost. We've closed or downsized roughly 20 facilities, about 5 million of square feet during that period, again, through '15, and about 15,000 employees, which is unfortunate. All-in then, if you look at the benefits, we mentioned to you before that we believe after '15, the benefit per year would be $400 million to $500 million per year. With what we've done, which we've had higher benefits on in the anticipated and what we have in place, we'll be at the high end or exceed that in terms of our benefits per year. And so it's a robust process. It's done by our product source planning group, with involvement across all the facilities, all the regions. There's been some discussion about big facilities. It's very hard to close a single source Decatur facility, in terms of the mining trucks, it would be the same for Peoria. So those things just don't dollar out in terms of return to shareholders. And we do it at net present value calculation through that. So I would say that we're continuing to look. We've added a few more in the mining space. If you go back to 2012, we were $66 billion in sales. We're $50 billion now. We've lost roughly $16 billion. 75% of that is mining. And we've held at a 25% decremental pull-through right in that range. And so there's a lot of things going on that support that, including lean and material cost. But I would say that we're pretty happy with that pull-through over that 3-year period. We've done that with little price and higher quality and growing market shares. So I'm not saying we won't have more to do, but that process is ongoing, and we've been pretty active in it.

componenttextpreview: I'll take that one. Doug Oberhelman here. We really haven't changed our priorities of cash at all. If anything, the top priority to maintain the balance sheet is, I think, becoming more important to us as the uncertainty around us continues on, if not inc
componenttext: I'll take that one. Doug Oberhelman here. We really haven't changed our priorities of cash at all. If anything, the top priority to maintain the balance sheet is, I think, becoming more important to us as the uncertainty around us continues on, if not increases. We reported that we're about, I guess, 37% or so of debt to debt and equity. That's been coming -- trending down and we'll trend that down throughout the year. We've bought $400 million of shares in the first quarter, which, I think, is a reasonable planning rate for the rest of the year, assuming our plan holds up. We will end the -- I have no doubt we'll end the year with cash, a lot of cash, as we did in the first quarter, over $7 billion. I think, in this area of uncertainty where, day to day,  one never knows what's going to happen, and having recently been burned on that in 2008 with a big downturn and a weak balance sheet, that's where we're going to be. And the other thing, and I've said this before, is that we are continually looking for growth opportunities and that strong balance sheet allows us lots of flexibility for growth, for protection, maintain our dividend, modestly increase it, as we've said before, and buy shares back. But I would say that we're in the driver's seat with cash generation, with our inventory turnover, raising our lean manufacturing, bring up cash. And as these other priorities work through, share buyback will likely, over time, continue to be an important thing for us. But in 2015, we're just planning right now on that $400 million until we -- kind of third quarter or so, given the uncertainties and the challenges we face and we see everyday in the marketplace.

You never say never about anything. But generally speaking, if you're going to produce and you're going to move things through -- oil through a pipeline, or you need the equipment to work to do that, if there is hesitation, if there's customers, maybe like mining, they have a possibility they could push out things like overhauls and rebuilds. That potentially could be a negative. I would say we're not really seeing a lot of that right now, outside of kind of the drilling and fracking where activity is off. Remember, though, and I think this needs to be said, a lot of our business in oil and gas, probably most of our business in oil and gas, is gas. And so far, that's held up pretty well. Demand for gas is good and the compression business is doing pretty well. So oil is just one piece of our oil and gas business.
Well, with that, I think, we're going to wrap it up. We're at the top of the hour. Thank you for joining us, and we'll talk to you again next quarter.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, Dana. And good morning and welcome, everyone, to our first quarter earnings call. I'm Mike DeWalt, Caterpillar's Vice President of Finance Services. And on the call today, I'm pleased to have our Chairman and CEO, Doug Oberhelman; and
componenttext:
Thank you very much, Dana. And good morning and welcome, everyone, to our first quarter earnings call. I'm Mike DeWalt, Caterpillar's Vice President of Finance Services. And on the call today, I'm pleased to have our Chairman and CEO, Doug Oberhelman; and our Group President and CFO, Brad Halverson. Remember, this call is copyrighted by Caterpillar Inc., and any use, recording or transmission of any portion of the call without the express written consent of Caterpillar is strictly prohibited. If you'd like a copy of today's call transcript, we'll be posting it in the Investors Section of our caterpillar.com website. It'll be in the section labeled Results Webcast.
This morning, we'll be discussing forward-looking information that involves risks and uncertainties and assumptions that could cause our actual results to differ materially from the forward-looking information. A discussion of some of the factors that either individually or in the aggregate could make actual results differ materially from our projections, that can be found in our cautionary statements under Item 1A, Risk Factors of our Form 10-K filed with the SEC in February of 2015, and it's also in our forward-looking statements language in today's financial release.
In addition, there's a reconciliation of non-GAAP measures that can also be found in this morning's release. And again, it's posted at caterpillar.com.
Okay. With that, let's get started. This morning, we'll be reviewing financial results for the first quarter and our revised outlook for 2015. And then there are about 3 points that I'd like to start with, actually, before we get into the details. And the first is that from a macro standpoint, in our view, not much has changed since our last earnings conference call in January. So we're staying pretty focused on the things that we do have some control of, and that's execution and operational improvement. Things like safety, quality, market share, efficiency, cost control, inventory turns and cash flow. And we continue to make progress.
And that brings me to my second point. Given the environment we're in, we were pleased with our first quarter results. Sales in the quarter were pretty close to what we expected, and we were pleased with the bottom line.
And that brings me to my third point. And that's a reminder of what we said in our year-end conference call back in January. We said that we expected the year to start out stronger than it would end, and that's still what we expect. And that's probably evident to you if you consider our first quarter actual results and what we're expecting for the first year.
Okay. With those 3 points, let's get into the quarter. Sales and revenues were $12.7 billion, and that was about 4% less than the $13.2 billion that we had in the first quarter last year. $342 million of that decline in sales was a result of the stronger dollar, and sales volume was unfavorable $295 million. Those 2 items were partially offset by a small improvement in price realization. That was $105 million, definitely in the right direction, but less than 1%.
Now the only region in the world that was up was North America, and that was up 9%. The North American improvement was pretty much across the board in each of our -- with each of our segments being in positive territory.
Outside of North America, that wasn't the case, and sales in each of our segments were down in Latin America, Europe, Africa, Middle East and in the Asia Pacific region. In total, sales and revenues were off 18% in Latin America, and sales of all of our equipment segments, that's Resource Industries, Construction Industries and Energy & Transportation, were down double digits. Construction was off 23%, and a sizable portion of that was the absence of a large order from the Brazilian government that we had in the first quarter last year and weaker construction activity in general in the region, particularly Brazil. Resource Industries was also down 23% in Latin America, reflecting continuing weakness in mining. And that's pretty much the case in every region. And Energy & Transportation was down 11%.
Sales and revenues in the Europe, Africa, Middle East region were down 12%. Construction Industries was off 14%, and most of that was from less favorable dealer inventory changes and the impact of currency on our sales.
Resource Industries was also off 14%, again, weak mining. And Energy & Transportation was down 8%.
Sales and revenues in Asia Pacific were down 13%, with the most significant decline in Construction Industries at 21%. Construction Industries were down substantially in China and lower in Japan as a result of the stronger dollar versus the yen. Our sales in Japan, which are in yen, essentially translated into fewer dollars. 
Okay. That's a recap of sales. Profit per share, though, was higher in the first quarter than it was in the first quarter a year ago. This year, it was $1.81 per share. A year ago, in the first quarter, it was $1.44 a share.
Now we had restructuring costs in both quarters. In the first quarter of last year, we had $0.17 per share of restructuring costs, and that was mostly from the actions that we took in our European operations. This year, we had $0.05 per share of restructuring costs in the first quarter. So excluding restructuring, profit per share improved from $1.61 a year ago to $1.86 in the current quarter -- in the first quarter. Now the primary reasons profit per share was up, number one, was the $120 million gain that we had from the sale of our remaining ownership in what was our third-party logistics business. We also had, as I mentioned a minute ago, $105 million of positive price realization, and we had $77 million of favorable currency impact that helped operating profit. And I'm just going to stop here for a minute and chat about currency. It's a subject that, for us, seems to be frequently misunderstood. Now I'd just like to clarify things again. We do have substantial sales that are in currencies other than the U.S. dollar. And when the dollar strengthens, that causes those sales to translate into fewer dollars, and that's a negative for our top line. That said, we also have substantial manufacturing operations and we source substantial purchase material outside the U.S. So our factories outside the U.S. allow sourcing outside the U.S. And that results in lower cost when translated to U.S. dollars. And that's exactly what happened this quarter. Sales translated into fewer dollars. As I mentioned a little bit ago, $342 million fewer. However, the impact on cost was favorable $419 million, and the net to operating profit was positive $77 million. While we're not 100% exactly balanced in our currency exposures, we do have reasonably offsetting sales and cost positions that usually keep the profit impact of exchange rate swings to a reasonably manageable level. 
Okay. That's the story on currency. I'll kind of get back to profit now. I'd already talked about the positive items, and offsetting those positives for the quarter, we did have lower sales volume, and that was negative to our operating profit, about $83 million, and we had higher cost. The most significant cost factor was a change in the timing of expense related to divesting of stock-based compensation. The timing change won't have an impact on the full year versus 2014, but it did add to cost in the first quarter. 
Okay. That's a quick run-through of profit versus the first quarter last year. Let's turn to the balance sheet and cash flow. Machinery, Energy & Transportation operating cash flow was a little over $1 billion in the quarter, but that was about $800 million lower than the first quarter last year. And most of that decline came from higher incentive compensation payments in the first quarter of this year, and they are based on performance in 2014. We used about $400 million of cash in the quarter to repurchase shares. And with relatively modest needs for CapEx this year, we currently expect to continue to repurchase shares in 2015. And as you might expect, the timing and the amount that we ultimately repurchase, well, that will be subject to business and market conditions as we progress through the year and on our cash deployment priorities. Our balance sheet remains strong with a debt to total capital ratio of 37.1%. And that's about right in the middle of our targeted 30% to 45% range. And it was slightly favorable versus year-end 2014. If you net cash with the debt, our net debt to capital ratio at the end of the quarter was 18.3%.
Now before we get into the revised outlook, I'll just recap changes in the order backlog over the last quarter because I suspect many of you are interested in that. We ended the first quarter with an order backlog of $16.5 billion, and that's about $800 million lower than the year-end 2014. The decline was split between Construction Industries and Resource Industries. You might have expected that Energy & Transportation would've also declined from year-end as a result of weakness in the oil industry. It was, in total, however, about flat. We did have a decline in the backlog because of weakness in oil, but that was about offset by an increase in the backlog for locomotives.
Okay. With that, let me go through the 2015 outlook. As I started out, in terms of overall world economic growth, we don't expect much change from the outlook that we provided with our year-end results in January. And the same goes for our sales and revenues, we're holding it at about $50 billion for 2015. 
Now while we're not changing the sales outlook, just as a reminder, we do expect 2015 to be over $5 billion lower than 2014. And as we said last January, and I'll reiterate today, the impact of substantially lower oil prices is the most significant reason for the decline. And we still think the most significant impact from oil will be from engines and other equipment that we sell for drilling and well servicing. And that's the spot where we expect a large drop in demand this year. We've already started to see the impact of that in our order backlog as new orders have not kept pace with sales, and the backlog has decline. And we'll start seeing that hit sales over the course of 2015. We also expect that indirect effects from substantially lower oil prices will be negative in 2015 versus 2014. In countries and in some regions of the U.S. where oil production is significant for either government receipts or for the local economies, it will likely be negative for sales of construction equipment and for our electric power generation business. In some cases, it can be fairly direct, like building a road to service a new well, or it can be very indirect, like construction spending in a country where the government relies on oil revenue to fund spending. Because many of those construction-related impacts are indirect, it does make it tough to measure. But anecdotally, we believe we're already starting to see the impact of that in our Construction business.
Now in addition to oil, there are several other factors that are contributing to the year-over-year decline in sales. The stronger dollar is a headwind to sales, but again, not profit. Commodity prices in mining are generally weak, particularly iron ore and coal, and that's negative for mining in our Resource Industries segment. With weaknesses in agriculture, we're expecting lower sales of industrial engines. And we expect our rail business to be down in 2015 after a great year in 2014. And we expect weakness in the Construction Industries of key developing countries like China and Brazil. And that was certainly evident in our first quarter. So that's a recap of our year-over-year changes, down from 2014, but no change in the top line outlook for 2015. We did raise the profit outlook again this morning. Our previous outlook was $4.60 per share all-in, and $4.75 excluding restructuring costs. This morning, we raised the profit outlook to $4.70 per share all-in, and $5 per share excluding restructuring costs. 
Now the changes from the previous outlook include more restructuring activity. We've increased our restructuring cost estimate from about $150 million expected for this year, up $100 million to about $250 million, with almost all of the increase related to facilities that produce mining products. We added the $120 million gain in the first quarter on the sale of our remaining ownership in the third-party logistics business. That wasn't in our previous outlook. And based on our first quarter actual results, we made some additional improvements to the profit outlook. While we held the top line and made a modest improvement to the bottom line of our outlook, 2015 is still shaping up to be an uncertain and challenging year. There continues to be softness in Latin America, particularly Brazil. China growth is concerning. The stability and scale of economic recovery in the United States remains concerning. Europe is still a question mark. Mining hasn't shown improvement yet. And while we're still planning a sharp decline in our oil-related sales in 2015, there's still a concern around that.
So to wrap up and move on to the Q&A portion of the call, sales and revenues in the first quarter were about as we expected, and we had a solid profit quarter. We repurchased 400 million of shares in the quarter. The balance sheet remains strong, and we're very focused on operational performance and cost control. But it still looks like a tough year and we've not seen meaningful signs of recovery in many of our cyclical businesses.
So with that, we're ready to move on to the Q&A portion of the call.

componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, we did have an inventory build in the first quarter. And we didn't talk a lot about that in the release. And partly because, I think, sometimes, it gets taken out of context. We expect an inventory build in the first quarter. The selling seas
componenttext: Yes, I mean, we did have an inventory build in the first quarter. And we didn't talk a lot about that in the release. And partly because, I think, sometimes, it gets taken out of context. We expect an inventory build in the first quarter. The selling season from dealers to end customers tends to be heavier in the summertime, and so dealers add the inventories ahead of summertime. That occurred this year in Construction Industries. We have, order of magnitude, 180 million dealers -- or 180 dealers roughly around the world. And at any given point in time, you've got some of them that probably have a little too much and some that have probably a little too little. If we look at our months of supply on hand, we kind of try to judge that in a reasonable range and we do look at that by region. And by and large, I think, our dealer inventory, we would say, is in a reasonable range. Now from here, we definitely believe it will come down over the course of the year. That happened last year. That's kind of normal to have a build in the first quarter and then have dealers sell that down as we go through the year.

componenttext: No, I wouldn't say that, Seth. I think, if you look at it sequentially, you always have to consider that we have some reasonable seasonality between the first quarter and the fourth quarter -- or fourth quarter to first quarter in discretionary cost. So fourth quarter was a pretty heavy quarter, first quarter was a pretty light quarter in terms of spending. So I think that has a lot to do with the sequential improvement. Now I think, Resource Industries margins will likely come down as the year progresses. We kind of said before we thought something around breakeven was probably reasonable. I think that we're going to add to spending over the course of the year. We've got some R&D programs that we need to do there. We talked about that in January. So my guess is, coming off of a pretty light quarter for cost and some increase in engineering as the year goes by, and probably not a lot of change in the top line, margin will probably moderate from where it's at.

componenttext: Yes, that's a very good question. We've been asking ourselves that. We've got customers with some parked equipment. We think, again, there's been some cannibalizing of equipment in the field. We're looking -- I think, customers are pushing out rebuild times. In our view, that can't keep happening, but it has been happening. So when that turns around, it's like the industry overall. It's a little bit hard to predict the timing. But we understand where both part sales and equipment sales are to what's, at least for equipment, a reasonable replacement level. It's far below that. componenttext: We've talked a bit about breakeven in Resource now. Can you talk to us about what we should expect profitability-wise, which were very impressive in both Construction and in E&T. componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think, this really goes kind of across the company. I'll touch on several of the segments. But we expect that the first quarter was kind of seasonally low on costs. So just as a matter of course, discretionary cost will go up a bit from the firs
componenttext: Yes. So I think, this really goes kind of across the company. I'll touch on several of the segments. But we expect that the first quarter was kind of seasonally low on costs. So just as a matter of course, discretionary cost will go up a bit from the first quarter level. We do plan to spend some more on R&D. And we talked about that last January. We're looking at negative mix. We'll have negative product mix in E&T because of the decline in the oil business that's coming. We also expect some negative mix in Construction Industries. If you look at what they sold in the first quarter, it was relatively balanced between -- we have 3 pieces of construction: earthmoving, excavation and building construction products, or BCP, our smaller equipment. So what we actually sold in the quarter, at least in terms of new equipment, was fairly balanced between those 3 subsectors. But if you look at what was ordered and what we think is going to happen for sales as the year unfolds, probably not a lot of change in total for construction, but a bit more of a shift to BCP, smaller machines. I think, part of that is, in countries like China where the selling season is very early in the year, that helps excavation sales and then that tails down later in the year. So we're looking at some negative mix in Construction as the year goes on. I don't think for the year, we're not, at least in our -- contemplated in our outlook, we're not going to fall below double digits for Construction. E&T operating profit percent will, I think, for sure, come down. Or I don't know, I guess, I can't say for sure. We would expect it would come down, and mostly because of the declines in the oil business, which is -- tends to be bigger, a little bit higher-margin product.

componenttextpreview: There's -- that's a good question, and it's interesting. When the numbers get this small, sometimes we end up talking too much about numbers that are relatively small. I mean, we had, for the company overall, $105 million of price realization. That's less
componenttext: There's -- that's a good question, and it's interesting. When the numbers get this small, sometimes we end up talking too much about numbers that are relatively small. I mean, we had, for the company overall, $105 million of price realization. That's less than 1%. I think, the segment that is doing -- the segments that are doing better right now are Construction and Energy & Transportation. Construction, in particular, did a little bit better. But part of that is really from a few -- 3 things. One is we had last year this big Brazilian order from the government. And while that was good volume, it was pretty low price. So without that, sort of our average price level is up a bit. We had some favorable geographic mix, and we did take list price increases, small, but up at the beginning of the year. So that all contributed a bit. I think, with Resource Industries, it's been down year-over-year for the last -- certainly, last couple of quarters. I can't remember the third, but probably in the third last year as well. It's just a tough business right now. It's dog eat dog. And although a lot of that product that we sell is dollar-based, the sales are conducted in dollars a lot in mining, some of our key competition like Komatsu probably has more of yen cost base than we do, and they're being aggressive. So it's a tough industry.

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I'll add -- it's Doug Oberhelman here. Mike said, dog eat dog. I'd rather say it cat eats dog. But be that as it may, we are seeing a very competitive marketplace right now. We did post up a little price realization in the first quarter, which I was v
componenttext: And I'll add -- it's Doug Oberhelman here. Mike said, dog eat dog. I'd rather say it cat eats dog. But be that as it may, we are seeing a very competitive marketplace right now. We did post up a little price realization in the first quarter, which I was very happy to see. But I will tell you, with the yen that's off over 50% in 3 years, euro, Brazilian currency, pound currency, off 20% to 30% in the last year. You know all of our competitors aren't in the U.S., so it's a -- it really is a competitive environment out there, but we are not giving up our pins goals, our market share goals. We're doing as well as we can be expected in a tough market that we are. Certainly, our cost management the last couple of years has helped that. Our lean manufacturing, where we generated cost advantage, has helped. And we're still very much focused on market share. But I would say the competition for every deal has gotten greater as we've seen this dollar strengthen.

componenttext: JPMorgan. My first question, it's really, I suppose it's to you, Doug. We talked about Europe and the euro being weak and what that's doing to help the European manufacturers' export, but are you seeing any signs of European economies getting any better at all? Or is that something that you think might be on the up-and-come going into '16?

headline: Caterpillar Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think it's in our future. I said on the show this morning that it seems to me that with the QE coming in by the ECB, with the euro that's off, like I said, 25% or so in a year's time, with energy prices where they are, the stimulus of all 3 of those, an
componenttext: I think it's in our future. I said on the show this morning that it seems to me that with the QE coming in by the ECB, with the euro that's off, like I said, 25% or so in a year's time, with energy prices where they are, the stimulus of all 3 of those, and not to mention continuing lowered rates, which has finally happened across Europe, I liken the Eurozone an awful lot to the period of, say, 2010, '11, and '12 in the U.S. where there was a lot of stimulus. We didn't see much growth, but we see better growth now. So I am convinced it's coming. I don't know if it will be -- when it will be. And I'm not going to predict that. But we still see, and I was just with several of our European dealers. We still have the North and South divide. I think, the Germans would say, they see some green shoots in that economy. We're not seeing it in our numbers. But they were a bit more optimistic in Germany. Of course, a euro at 1.07, 1.08 really benefits those exporters. So I think we're in the early stages of what will be a recovery. I don't think it's going to be a boom, and I think it's going to be an anemic growth, probably looking a lot like what we've seen here. But it will feel better when it happens, for sure, Ann.

componenttext: I'll take that, Mike. I just came back from Solar in San Diego 2 days ago and got a pretty good briefing. They would not speculate and really don't know much beyond that into '16 as yet. I would say, around gas compression, of course, which is the big piece of solar business, that has held up. And there's a lot of pipeline work going on. There's a lot of pressure behind it that's required and that's our turbine and compressor in most cases. So I'd say, they're -- it's, again, it's a challenging environment, but gas compression for the rest of the year, they're pretty much, I think, going to end up where we thought they would be, and that's good. And we're concentrating on '15. But Solar, I think, has got a year that we're pretty confident about it, that's baked into here as well.
